This skill is about spending 1-on-1 time with Your Teen. 😃
Spending 1-on-1 time with Your Teen will help you build trust, respect, and a  positive relationship between you and Your Teen.
Here’s a video on spending 1-on-1 time with your teen.
Here’s an audio message on spending 1-on-1 time with your teen.
Here are three tips to remember to help you make the most of spending 1-on-1 time with your teen: DAY, PLAY, and STAY.

1️⃣ *DAY - Try to do it every day*

⏰ Spend 5 minutes (or more!) with your teen each day.

2️⃣ *PLAY - Let them choose the activity*

⏰ Ask to spend time with your Teen.

⚽ Let them choose what to do or talk about.

🎈Try different activities together.

😃 Have fun!

3️⃣ *STAY - Focus on your teen*

📺 Switch off the TV and put aside phones.

👀 Look at your teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention.
 
💛 Accept your teen and avoid judgement.
 
👂 Rephrase back what your teen says. It shows you are really listening to them.

✅⬜️

This skill is about praise. 🎉 How did the message above make you feel? We all feel better when others notice the good things we do. It’s even better when it is by someone we love.
Praising Your Teen when they behave in a good way will make them want to behave that way more often. It also creates a positive and loving relationship with between you and your teen. ⭐
Here's a video on the importance of praise. When you bring attention to positive behaviours, your teen is likely to keep behaving positively and feel good about themselves!
Here's an audio message on how you can focus on positive behaviour by praising your teen! 👂

When you bring attention to positive behaviours, your teen is likely to behave positively more often and feel good about themselves!

Here are 4 simple tips for praising your teen:

1️⃣ *SEE IT*

👀 Look for anything good or helpful your teen does.

⏸ Take a moment to notice that they are doing it.

2️⃣ *SAY IT*

🏆 Praise them when you see them do something you like.

✅ Tell them specifically what they have done well.

🎉 Be enthusiastic and really mean it!

🔄 This means they are more likely to do it again.

3️⃣ *REPEAT IT*

🌷 Look for something to praise your teen for every day.

🔶 Even if it is something really small, keep doing it.

4️⃣ *KEEP IT POSITIVE*

💡 Make sure you focus on something your teen has done well.

🌈 Keeping it positive reminds your teen that you notice them and care.

✅⬜️

Here is a video message about talking about your feelings with Your Teen.
Here is an audio message about talking about feelings with Your Teen.
Here are some tips for how you can help Your Teen learn how to cope with their emotions following these six steps: OPEN, SHARE, LEARN, TALK, NOTICE, CARE.

1️⃣ *OPEN*

👂 Listen to your teen when they share how they are feeling.

💛 Accept how they feel.

🧸 Give them comfort.

2️⃣ *SHARE*

😃 Share your own feelings with Your Teen.

🌈This sets a good example and shows your teen that it's okay to share their own feelings.

3️⃣ *LEARN*

💡 Learn about different emotions.

😃 There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid.

😔 As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

4️⃣ *TALK*

😒 It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. 

👋 Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

💡 Learn to identify your own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.

5️⃣ *NOTICE*

🌈 Begin to notice all emotions. 

😃 You can also share positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.

💙 It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

6️⃣ *CARE*

🌷 Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved.

💚 Remind Your Teen that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

✅✅⬜️

This skill is about taking care of yourself. 🌱
It is normal to feel stressed as your teen develops. As they grow, your relationship changes. To handle this change smoothly, you must care for yourself.
Self-care is an activity you do for yourself, so you feel better and less stressed. 💚
Press play for a simple activity that may help you with stress. ▶️
Here’s an audio message on how to take care of yourself. 🎵
Here is a simple stretching and movement activity that may help you with stress.

Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. 
...
Push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. 
...
Stretch to both sides. 
...
Stretch to the front and to the back.

Let your hands hang by your side. 
...
Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. 
...
Release your shoulders as you relax your body.

Relax your arms and let them swing to the front and back. Take 4 deep breaths while you do this. This is good for your lower back.
...
Relax your arms and let your arms to swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from the ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!

Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out. 
...
Raise and lower your arms, breathing in and out,  4 more times.

Take a moment to reflect on your experience. 
...
Remember that you can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.

Here is what you need to know about your teen’s developing mind and how to talk with them about it.

1️⃣ *THE DEVELOPING MIND*

🌱 Your teen’s brain hasn’t changed this fast since they were a baby. 

🚩 Teens sometimes behave in risky ways as they test what is possible and allowed, especially if it is pleasurable or fun. 

❗ Teens don’t always have the ability to always think ahead about how their behaviours might impact themselves or other people.

2️⃣ *BECOMING MORE INDEPENDENT*

⭐ Teens are on their way to becoming adults.

🌈 They are becoming better at sharing their ideas and are thinking more about long term goals and their future.

3️⃣ *HOW TO SUPPORT YOUR TEEN*

To support your teen:

🔑 Guide their choices by balancing rules and limits with independence. 

🏅 You can give them more freedom to make their own choices when they show they can be responsible and take responsibility for their actions.

✨ Be supportive, loving, and positive with your teen. This helps them feel safe and secure around you, and they're more likely to come to you for help or advice when they need it.

✅✅⬜️

Here is what you need to know about your teen’s social life and how to talk with them about it.

1️⃣ *THE SOCIAL LIVES OF TEENS*

⚽ Having friends is very important to your teen because it helps them learn how to be a good friend and understand other people's feelings better. This is a big part of growing up and becoming an adult.

👀 Your teen may want to feel like they belong with their peers, and do things that others think are cool. They might talk or dress like others while figuring out who they are. 

😔 Sometimes, when teens have a hard time making friends, they might be picked on or bullied by other kids.

2️⃣ *HOW TO SUPPORT YOUR TEEN*

🎨 Let Your Teen try different clothing and hair styles and spend time with different people. Show them you accept them, just as they are. 

⏰ Tell Your Teen what you expect of them at home, but give them the chance to make safe choices, such as how to spend their free time.

3️⃣ *THE FACTS*

Here are some facts to share with your teen:

💙 Good friends look out for you, care about you, include you in activities, and treat you with respect. 

🚩A bully is someone who keeps trying to hurt others, either by making them feel bad or using their strength to be mean. But if someone only does it once, it's not bullying.

🌈 To stop bullying in school, it's important to be kind and respectful to others. This makes everyone feel happy and safe at school.

This skill is about supporting your teen to find joy and have fun while learning. 😃
Parents play an important role in how your teen learns and develops in and out of school.
Here’s a video message on supporting your teen to find joy while learning!
Here’s an audio message on supporting your teen to find joy while learning!
Here are three tips to help you facilitate joyful and fun learning with your teen.

1️⃣ *PLAY*

🌱 Giving your teen time to have fun and be joyful  improves their  physical and mental health AND their ability to learn and remember important facts!

⚽ Play games

⏰ If your teen starts to feel overwhelmed with school work, help them reduce their stress by taking a pause or having fun together.

💡Incorporate your teen’s interests in their learning.

2️⃣ *BE POSITIVE*

🎈Few teens actually enjoy homework. You can empathise with their frustration, but remind them why homework matters: it strengthens what they have learned at school, and teaches them how to manage their time wisely.

😃 Encourage and praise your teen when they are learning.

3️⃣ *ALLOW CREATIVITY*

🎨 Allow your teen to be creative when learning. For example, encourage your teen to draw or go outside to help their learning.
 
✨If your teen is interested in a new topic, talk to them about it and  encourage them to explore and find out more about it.

💙 Set a good example: Let your teen see you being creative, trying something new, even if you are not good at it yet.

✅⬜️

This skill is about helping your teen learn by setting goals. 😃
Here’s a video message on supporting your teen to find joy while learning!
Here’s an audio message on supporting your teen to find joy while learning!
Here are three tips to help your teen learn:

1️⃣ *SET GOALS*

🏁 Support your teen to set goals for something they want to do. 

📖 Help them make their goals specific and measurable. The goals should be something that they can complete within a specific amount of time.

🎓 Help them understand the connection between learning and achieving their goals.

🌱This builds their motivation to learn.

2️⃣ *ASK QUESTIONS*

❓ Encourage your teen to ask questions.

😃 Ask your teen questions.

💡 Don’t worry if you do not know the answer. Try finding the answer together by looking online, or asking teachers in your school.
 
🎓Curiosity will help your teen’s brain grow!

3️⃣ *MAKE CONNECTIONS*

📖 Ask your teen to connect new information to things they already know, such as one of their interests or a topic from school.

🔑This develops and promotes deeper thinking and understanding of concepts.

❌Ask your teen to keep the phone away from the study space.

Today’s parenting skill is about helping your teen know how to learn from their mistakes.
Learning from our mistakes can help us avoid them in the future. It can also help us be more supportive to ourselves and less harsh when things do not go well. 😃
Here’s a video message on supporting your teen to create a space for them to learn.
Here’s an audio message on supporting your teen to create a space for them to learn.
Here are four tips that you can use to help your teen learn from their mistakes:

1️⃣ *TALK*

👂 Create space and time for your teen to talk with you about their life. 

💙 If their day was challenging, listen to them, and give space to let them share.

💛 Give them support and show you care. Tell them, "that sounds difficult.”

2️⃣ *PRAISE EFFORT*

💛 Praise your teen for the effort they put into their learning even if they did not succeed.

✨ Effort is more important than mastering a specific skill.

3️⃣ *ALLOW FOR MISTAKES TO HAPPEN*

🌱 Allow your teen to make mistakes. Let them learn from their own mistakes so they can learn and grow.

❓ It is tempting to want to solve every problem for your teen, especially when you know better. This will not teach them to solve their own problems.

😃 Talk to your teen about their mistakes and allow them figure out a way to solve their problems and do better next time.

4️⃣ *SHARE*

📖 Try and share your own failures with your teen and discuss how they helped you develop and grow.

✅This helps your teen learn that you do not have to be perfect all the time.

✅⬜️

This skill is about how to keep Your Teen safe online. There is so much to share. We will cover online safety over two lessons. 📱
Teens are spending a lot of time online. Being connected helps them stay positive and learn more! But there are also some risks and dangers. 🚩

Keeping your teen safe online is important to help them learn more about the digital world. 📱

Keeping Your Teen safe online is an important step to help them be part of the digital world. 📱When it comes to online safety, there are four tips to keep in mind: 
LEARN, PROTECT, BUILD HABITS, and BUILD TRUST.

Today, we are learn about LEARN and PROTECT. 
The next lesson will cover BUILD HABITS and BUILD TRUST.

1️⃣ *LEARN the dangers of being online:* 

🚩 CONTENT: Your teen might come across harmful content, such as violence, hateful speech, pornography, wrong information, or hating women, people with disabilities, or other races, religions, sexualities, or from other countries.

🚩 CONTACT: Adults might pretend to be teens and ask for sexual pictures or to meet with your teen through an online platform.

🚩 CONDUCT: Sometimes, teens or strangers can say or do hurtful things online.

2️⃣ *PROTECT - Keep your teen safe online*

✅ Talk to your teen about which apps and websites are safe and which are not. Discuss why!

✅ Help your teen learn how to make strong passwords to protect their devices.

Keeping Your Teen safe online is an important step to help them be part of the digital world. 📱 Today, we are learning how to BUILD HABITS and BUILD TRUST.

1️⃣ *BUILD HABITS*

Set up safe online habits at home. 

✅ Plan phone-free times in your house, like during meals, homework, or in bed.

✅ Only let your teen chat online with people they already know. They should never share personal information in a chat room or with strangers.

✅ Before completing forms that ask for personal information, check that the web address begins with https://. Websites that begin with http:// may not be secure.

✅ Help your teen create strong passwords for their accounts. They should be long, not include obvious personal information like your name or birthday, and include upper and lower case letters, numbers and symbols."

✅ Tell your teen not to click on pop-ups that ask them to download or pay for anything.

2️⃣ *BUILD TRUST with your teen.*

✅ Together, look at websites, social media, games, and apps your teen uses. 

✅ Ask questions - this helps you learn more about your teen’s interests!

✅If you come across anything worrying together, talk about it with your teen.

✅Tell your teen that they should tell an adult if they feel scared, unsafe or upset about something online.

In this goal, we are learning about the four steps to building a family budget with our teens. The first step is identifying needs and wants. 💰

Managing how money is spent is important to ensure that parents are able to provide for our teens. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. Talking with your teen about the difference between something that you need and something that you want can help them understand how to prioritise spending limited money.
Press play to watch a video about needs and wants.
Press play to hear a message about needs and wants.
Let's learn about the first step to family budgeting with your teen!

1️⃣ *IDENTIFY NEEDS*

Make a list of things that you or your teen think you cannot live without. Things that are important for your family to survive. 💚

For example food 🍚, soap to wash hands, or medicine 🏥.

2️⃣ *IDENTIFY WANTS*

Make a list of things that you or your teen want. These are things that would be nice to have but not essential 🎁. 

For example the latest version of a smartphone, new toy, or magazine.

3️⃣ *TALK*

People often see things in different ways. You may find that your teen sees one thing as a NEED while you see it as a WANT. Talk with your teen about why you feel differently, this will help you to understand each other and can make decisions together about what to spend money on. 💰

✅⬜️

Congratulations! You have reached the final step to family budgeting with your teen: make a saving plan. You should be very proud of your dedication. 💰

Making a saving plan can help you prepare for crises while also having funds for your teen’s education and other things that you may need in the future. Even a small amount each month can make a big difference over time.

Here are some tips on how to make a savings plan with your teen:

*WHY SAVE*

Discuss with your teen different reasons that you might want to save money. These could include:

1️⃣Preparing for emergencies

2️⃣Buying something nice for you or your teen or do something fun as a family

3️⃣Planning for future big expenses like improvements on your home or for your teen’s education

*HOW TO SAVE*

Set a target amount that you want to save. Look at your monthly budget and discuss with your teen how much you can save each week and each month.

*WHERE TO SAVE*

Discuss with your teen different ways to keep money safe for future use. These could include:

1️⃣Saving at a bank

2️⃣Keeping money safe at home

3️⃣Keeping money in a savings and loan group

4️⃣Buying livestock like goats or cattle 

Discuss with your teen about the potential good things (benefits) and problems (risks) of each way of saving money. 
Decide which way of saving money would work best for the family.
❗ If you can try and save even a tiny amount for the future or for an emergency. This can make a big difference over time.

*GET SUPPORT*

Your government or community groups may be giving money, vouchers, or food parcels to families in need. 

Think about whether there are places in your community that provide support.

This skill is about learning to be kind to yourself. ☀️ Imagine you had a friend who was feeling bad about making a big mistake. 😣 What would you say to them if they told you about it? What tone of voice would you use?

Now think about how you talk to yourself when you make a mistake. Is it different? 
Often, we don’t treat ourselves as well as we treat our friends and family.
Being kind to ourselves helps us deal with hard things that happen. When we are kind to ourselves, we can be kind to others.
Here’s a video to give you 3 steps for being kind to yourself. It’s such an important skill!
Here’s an audio message to give you three steps for being kind to yourself. It’s such an important skill!
Here are three steps to help you be kind to yourself. In a few days, we will learn to use the same steps with our teens, but first, let’s practise with ourselves: NOTICE, SAY IT’S OKAY, BE KIND.

1️⃣ *NOTICE*

😣 Sometimes, it seems easier to ignore negative feelings so they will go away.

❗ But ignoring them only means they will come up later - or get worse!

🚩 When you feel any negative emotion, notice that you are feeling it.

⭐ It can be helpful to name this feeling for yourself.

2️⃣ *SAY IT’S OK*

🛑Take a pause or a few deep breaths.

💛 Now, say to yourself, “It’s OK,” because it is OK to have negative feelings - everyone does sometimes!

😔 Often, these feelings come up for a good reason and can tell us something. It really is OK!

3️⃣ *BE KIND*

💚 When you notice these feelings, it’s important to be kind and patient with yourself.

🎁 Think about what kind of advice a loving friend or family member might give you now.

✅⬜️

Before we finish, let's practise self-care.

Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready, open your eyes again.
Listen to your breath.

Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?
Talk to someone.
Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. 
Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment.
How do you feel now?
A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.

Parents sometimes need help and support just like teens do!

This skill is about helping our teens with stress. 
Many things can be stressful to your teen: a break-up, stress in your home, being bullied, and exams. These are big life challenges for a teen.

Teens’ brains are still growing. They don’t always have good skills for dealing with stress. 

Some teens feel a lot of stress. In response, they might feel anxious, withdraw from others, or even feel sick. Some teens may respond with violence, self-harm, or by using drugs or alcohol to cope.

You can help your teen cope with their stress by supporting them through it.

Here’s an audio message to give you some tips on how to support your teen when they are feeling stressed. 💛
Here are some tips you can use to help your teen when they are feeling stressed:

1️⃣ *NOTICE*

👀 Look for signs that your teen is feeling stressed. Their behaviour will often show when they are stressed. 

🚩 They might get angry a lot, want to be alone all the time, be unable to focus, feel tired often, or not feel like doing any work.

2️⃣ *TALK*

❓ Let your teen share about what makes them stressed. Try to accept what they say. 

😣 They might feel a lot of stress about something that feels small to us. To them, it might feel huge!

💛 Let them tell you about what gives them stress without judging them.

This skill is about supporting your teen when they are having a difficult time by showing them kindness and support them.

Being a teen can be very stressful, and they might feel like there is a lot going on or too much is being asked of them. 😣 This can lead to negative behaviours that impact their wellbeing and confidence. You can help them by telling them you get it and showing them love through it. 💙
Here’s a video about showing your teen kindness.
Here's an audio message on treating your teen with compassion. 👂
Remember the tips we looked at about being kind to yourself? Here are some tips on how you can support your teen when they are having a difficult time:

1️⃣ *NOTICE*

👀 Look out for when your teen is frustrated or upset with themselves about something. Look out for common behaviour, like angry outbursts, shouting, or spending lots of time alone.

2️⃣ *LISTEN*

👂Give space for your teen to share what they are experiencing.

💛Try to accept what your teen is saying.

🔄 You may want to show that you are listening by repeating back what you hear

3️⃣ *SAY IT’S OK*

🎈 Let your teen know that their feelings are normal and that everyone feels like this sometimes. 

💛 Tell them it is okay to feel like this.
Of course, not every feeling or situation is okay. Remember, if you need help in a crisis, you can type HELP in ParentText to receive a list of community resources where you may find support.

4️⃣ *COMFORT*

⭐ Comfort your teen, and remind them to be kind to themselves.

⏰ Be patient and give them time to work through their emotions.

💡 If you think it could help, speak to them about what they could do differently next time.

Here are three steps on knowing the warning signs: NOTICE, DON’T WAIT, GET HELP.

1️⃣ *NOTICE*

👀 Notice the warning signs and behaviour that could show that there may be a problem with your teen’s mental health:

A lot sleeping or no sleeping
Loss of interest in hobbies
Sudden loss in school and decrease in grades at school
Sudden changes in personality, for example a lot of anger
Feeling sad, empty, or worthless
A lot of worry
Irritability or restlessness
Not wanting to be around people or take part in activities
Extreme panic
Drug and alcohol use
Signs of self-harm, such as cut marks
Expressing ideas about killing oneself

2️⃣ *ACT EARLY*

❗ If you notice some of these signs, it's time to take action. 

❌ These warning signs can develop into serious problems. 

🌱 Early intervention can have a positive impact on your teens well-being.

3️⃣ *GET HELP*

😃 Respect your teen’s privacy. Talk to your teen about what kind of support they might need. 

💚 Support for you is also really important. Ask for help if you need it. Having a support system can make all the difference.

Before you can care for your teen, you must first care for yourself. This skill is about learning how to manage your stress.
Managing your stress is really important for your health and mental well-being and will help you develop positive relationships with your teen. 🔑
Here's a video to help you manage your stress 😃

Here are 3 steps to help you manage your stress:

1️⃣ *REFLECT*

📝 Grab a pen and piece of paper. 

⏸ Take a moment to think about how much stress you are feeling. 

⭐ Write down from 0 to 100 how stressed you are. 

❓ How does stress feel for you? Do you feel tense, do you have low energy? Are you finding it hard to sleep and focus, or like everything is too much? Write these down. 

🌱 Knowing how your body responds to stress can help you manage it.

2️⃣ *IDENTIFY*

🚩 Write down the main stressors in your life. 

💡 Knowing why you feel stress can help you address the stressor and learn how to cope and manage it. 

🎨 Now identify what activities make you happy. What do you enjoy doing? 

💚 There are different things you can do to care for yourself, such as walking, praying, and reading. Activities that help you manage stress are called ‘self-care.’

3️⃣ *ROUTINE*

✨ Reflect on your daily life: how can you reduce your stress?

☕ How many self-care activities can you fit in your routine?

⏰ Try and make time for at least one self-care activity a day.

This skill is about what to do when our teens misbehave. 🚩 It is normal for teens to misbehave sometimes when they are tired, scared, hungry, or learning independence.
Stop it before it starts! When your teen gets restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: say, "Come, let's play a game together!" ⚽
Redirecting behaviour is a way to reduce your teen’s negative behaviour by redirecting them to more positive ones. ➡️
Here's a video that helps you redirect your teen's behaviour when they misbehave. ☀️
Here's an audio message that helps you redirect your teen's behaviour when they misbehave. ➡️
There are four steps to redirecting behaviour: BE CALM, QUICK, CLEAR, and POSITIVE.

1️⃣ *BE CALM*

✅ Take a few breaths before asking your teen to do something else.

✅ Speak with a calm voice.

2️⃣ *BE QUICK*

⏰ Ask your teen to do something else, distract them, before the behaviour begins or gets worse.

💡 This is much easier than using consequences after they do something!

3️⃣ *BE CLEAR*

✅ Rather than saying what you DON’T like or want, tell your teen what you DO want them to do.
For example, say:

✨ “Please speak more softly.”

✨ “Remember to walk inside the house.”

This way, it is easier for them to follow! ⭐

4️⃣ *BE POSITIVE*

✅ Praise your teen when they behave well!

✅ Redirecting your teen to a positive behaviour will help you avoid conflict.

✅ It will also help them know what you expect from them!

✅⬜️

This skill is about learning how to solve problems with Your Teen. 👂

As teens get older, they do more by themselves, and sometimes act outside of the rules we made to keep them safe. 🚗 This can cause conflict at home. Learning to solve these problems together can make your teen's behaviour better.
Here's a video to help you teach your teen problem-solving skills.
Here's an audio message to help you teach your teen problem-solving skills.
When something happens, take a deep breath. Then, help your teen work on the problem with these 4 steps:

1️⃣ *KNOW IT*

✅ Put the problem into words.

✅ Talk to your teen about what the problem is.

2️⃣ *SOLVE IT*

✅ Together, think of possible solutions to this problem.

✅ What could you or your teen do differently in this situation in the future?

3️⃣ *TRY IT*

✅ Choose one solution together.

✅ Try it next time you are in a similar situation.

4️⃣ *TEST IT*

✅ Ask yourself, “Did it work?” 

✅ If yes, great!

✅ If not, talk to your teen about trying another solution next time

This skill helps with what to do when your teen has already done something wrong… 😔

Teenagers are still learning who they are and how they want to be in the world. Consequences teach our teens that their actions affect themselves and others. ❗ It is important for our teens to learn as they get older. Giving clear consequences teaches teens more than hitting or shouting does.
Here's a video that explains how you can use consequences to help your teen act responsibly and respectfully.
Here's an audio message that explains how you can use consequences to help your teen act responsibly and respectfully.
Here are 3 simple steps for using consequences when your teen behaves badly:

1️⃣ *BE CALM*

✅ Shouting at our teens only makes things worse.

✅ Take some deep breaths or walk away if you need to.

✅ Then, respond in a calm, clear way.

2️⃣ *BE FAIR*

✅ Give your teen the option to behave before giving a consequence. For example, say, “Either you do your homework now, or you cannot watch your favourite T.V. show tonight.”

✅ Talk about consequences for breaking household rules when you set them so Your Teen knows them already.

✅ Notice if your teen is experiencing a consequence to their action already.

3️⃣ *BE POSITIVE*

✅ Praise your teen for actions you want to see more of so that they know what they are doing right, too!

✅ See if you can avoid giving consequences at all, by redirecting them to something else before they behave badly.

✅ Consequences help our teens learn how their actions affect others - and to think before they act.

✅Using consequences can be hard at first, but will be easier with practice!

When we do not feel safe, we are allowed to do anything to get away. We can USE OUR VOICE and USE OUR BODIES to protect ourselves.

1️⃣ *USE YOUR VOICE*

When we do not feel safe, we are allowed to do anything to get away.

Remember the last scenario, where the man tried to force the girl into his car? How could the girl use her voice to get away? She might shout…
‘No!’
“Someone help me!”
“I will call the police if you touch me again”
"Do not touch my bum”

Or she might try something else…
“I will do anything you want, just please don’t hurt me.”
“No lift for me, thanks. Last time I got a lift I threw up EVERYWHERE!”
“I can see that you are angry. Let’s sit together and talk about it.”
“I will give you my phone if you let me go.”
Consider, what would you do? There’s no wrong answer.

2️⃣ *USE YOUR BODY*

When our voice does not stop the situation, we can use our bodies to defend ourselves. You should know your attacker’s targets and do what you can to hurt them:
Scratch
Pull
Punch
Kick 
Twist

There are four primary targets to know: 
1. Eyes
2. Throat
3. Groin
4. Knees

And seven secondary targets: 
1.Temple 
2. Ears 
3. Nose 
4. Solar Plexus (the space between the ribs) 
5. Fingers 
6. Shin 
7. In Step (top of the feet)

In a dangerous situation, we may not know what to do and freeze or respond in an angry way – this is normal. These tools can help keep you and your teen safe: KNOW IT, SEE IT, SAY IT, DO IT

1️⃣ *KNOW IT*

Know the difference between healthy and unhealthy relationships. If you are attacked, know that it is never your fault. You are allowed to say and do what is needed to stay safe and get away – do not worry about what others may think. You are worth being defended. You are strong and powerful.

2️⃣ *SEE IT*

When someone makes you (or someone else) feel uncomfortable with what they say or do, that is never okay! We all have the right to feel safe, especially at home. Follow your intuition. When you feel attacked with words or actions, your goal is to get away.

3️⃣ *SAY IT*

Your voice can stop many attacks. Yell ‘No!’, call for help, warn of consequences, name the behaviour, act crazy, pretend to go along to buy time, use humour, calm them down, or negotiate. Be clear, confident, and direct. Speak using your voice, body language, and eye contact.

4️⃣ *DO IT*

When our voice is not changing the situation, we can use our bodies. Know the ‘weapons’ on your body and know the ‘targets’ on your attacker’s body. Use what is free on your body that you can fight with and what is open on the attacker’s body to hit.
If you do get hurt by someone, remember it is never your fault. Ask someone you trust for help, and make sure your teen knows they can tell you anything so you can find a solution together.

This skill is about learning how to respond to crises when they happen. ❗
When our teens share something that is very hard or upsetting to them, we need to remember to stay calm, listen, and be open so that they feel supported. 💛
Here's a video about how to support your teen when they are in difficult situations. 💙
Here's an audio message on how you can support your teen when they are experiencing difficult situations. 👂
Here are some things you can do to support your teen when they share something difficult with you:

1️⃣ *BREATHE: Take a pause*

🌱 Take a deep breath so you can respond calmly.

💛 Ask yourself, “What does my teen need right now?”

2️⃣ *LISTEN: Ask your teen what is going on *

👂 Let your teen share with you what they need.

👀 Notice what they are feeling and tell them what you notice so they feel heard.

💙 Tell your teen that you are there for them and love them.

3️⃣ *RESPOND: What might help what is going on?*

🔶 You might need to help your teen talk about their feelings or redirect their focus.

➡️ You might need to talk about the actions that you or your teen could take to help with what has happened.

⏸ You can give consequences later if needed. Right now, your teen needs you to be there for them with love.

✅ Remember, you can always type HELP to ParentText and get information about resources in your community where you may receive help.

4️⃣ *COMFORT: Be there for your teen*

🌷 It can be hard to see your teen feeling upset or confused, but there is a lot you can do to support them.

💚 They need you to accept them and comfort them when difficult things are going on.

🎈 Remind your teen again that you love them, and thank them for sharing with you.

Treating each other as equals and making decisions together can have a big impact on how we feel and can help our children feel loved and safe. ⭐

🔄 If you forget, keep trying! 

⭐ Asking for their opinion shows that you care and want them to be involved.

3️⃣ *TIMING MAKES A DIFFERENCE*
 
⏰If you have a decision to make, bring it up during a time when you and your partner are not too busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening.

4️⃣ *PRACTICE MAKES PERFECT*

⏰ It can take time to get used to making decisions together. 

🔄 Give yourself time and keep trying! 

😃 Remember that by communicating with your partner, you will both eventually start to feel more comfortable talking and sharing decisions.
